awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: Internet of Things (IOT) Safety Device and System for Micro-Mobility Products
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is the development of new technologies to enhance the safety of micro-mobility vehicles and fleets (bicycles, electronic bikes, and electric scooters). Micro-mobility has a high potential to reduce congestion, emissions, and noise pollution in urban settings.  These vehicles can address many first- and last-mile transportation challenges. The technology developed in this project will integrate low-cost sensors, advanced machine learning and model-based algorithms with Internet of Things (IOT)-based technologies for micro-mobility safety devices. Furthermore, IOT-based early detection and warning systems can address safety concerns in the use of micro-mobility, resulting in the development of strong ecosystems.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will develop and evaluate a cost-effective. innovative, IOT technology and turn it into a product and service that are essential to the safety and reliability of the micro-mobility vehicles and fleets. The technology involves predicting likely future failures in vehicle braking components and systems in advance of their occurrence as well as early detection of hazardous driving conditions (due to misbehavior of riders, road conditions, or weather conditions).  The solution will issue warnings to the rider and proactive alerts with actionable recommendations (e.g., for proactive maintenance). The project will develop and evaluate model-based and machine-learning-assisted algorithms for the detection, isolation, and prediction of failures and hazardous driving conditions as well as the associated level of confidence in the accuracy of the decisions. The performance of the safety device and operation under experimental conditions and constraints will be evaluated using end-to-end simulation and a testbed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we developed and evaluated an innovative and cost-effective Internet-of-Things (IoT) technology designed to enhance the safety and reliability of micro-mobility vehicles and fleets. This technology enables proactive failure prediction in vehicle braking components and systems, issuing smart alerts with actionable recommendations to operators (e.g., for proactive maintenance). The goal is to turn this technology into a viable product and service that addresses critical needs in the micro-mobility sector.

Our project began with a thorough customer discovery process to understand market needs and opportunities. We interviewed stakeholders across various segments, including ride-sharing companies, last-mile delivery companies, riders, bike shops, and manufacturers. These insights revealed that last-mile delivery companies are our initial target market, as they operate on high-duty cycles and require just-in-time delivery. For them, our technology promises increased availability, reduced downtime, and improved operational efficiency and safety.

We developed, tested, and validated simulation models of e-bike braking dynamics, incorporating subsystem nonlinearities and interactions, as well as environmental factors like potholes, road surface conditions, and inclines. These models enable a deeper understanding of micro-mobility vehicle braking functions and facilitate the diagnosis and prognosis of system faults, paving the way for the development of safety devices like anti-lock braking and anti-dive control systems.

To support data collection, algorithm development, and validation, we created an IoT test bed. This test bed includes a standard e-bike equipped with sensors to measure forces, displacements, 3-D acceleration, 3-D motion rates, and wheel speeds. A controller is used for data collection and processing, with an IoT module for cloud connectivity via Wi-Fi, cellular, Bluetooth, and Ethernet.

Our work represents a significant contribution to the field of fault detection, isolation, and prognosis for micro-mobility vehicle braking systems—a previously underexplored area. Using a model-based approach, we developed health indicators for fault detection, fault models for isolation, and remaining useful life estimation for prognosis. In parallel, we employed AI-based approaches. Experimental data and simulation outputs generated big data for AI training, with the K-nearest neighbors method yielding the highest accuracy. By combining model-based and AI-driven approaches, we achieved enhanced accuracy and robustness. The resulting application monitors braking system health, providing state-of-health indications for each component and issuing proactive maintenance alerts as needed.

The development of smart alerts with actionable recommendations and accurate timing for scheduled maintenance, coupled with remaining useful life information, is vital to building an efficient and effective proactive maintenance system. This IoT device and service enhance the safety of micro-mobility vehicles and fleets. By addressing safety concerns, our technology supports the growth of micro-mobility as a sustainable mode of transportation, reducing car usage, shared parking spaces, fossil fuel consumption, and congestion. Additionally, it promotes public health by encouraging physical activity, lowers transportation costs, and fosters productivity and economic growth.

Beyond the transportation sector, our IoT-based technologies hold promise for applications in semiconductor manufacturing, where downtime can be costly, as well as in the electrification of transportation and medical equipment maintenance, where safety and availability are critical.

Lastly, the mentoring and training of graduate students by the project’s principal investigator have had a broader impact on developing the next generation of scientists and engineers, providing them with valuable experience in addressing real-world engineering challenges.

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2024
Modified by: Mutasim Salman
